channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: A health care worker in protective gear treated a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last month.

item.title: Murray Olderman, Who Both Wrote and Drew About Sports, Dies at 98
item.description: At a time when caricatures were a regular part of the nation’s sports pages, Mr. Olderman thrived as a cartoonist. He also wrote features and columns.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein

item.title: Despite Unrest, Treasury Dept. Has No Plans to Speed Tubman to the $20 Note
item.description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has maintained that a future administration will decide whether Harriet Tubman will replace Andrew Jackson on the bill.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: ‘A Slap in the Face’: Black Veterans on Bases Named for Confederates
item.description: President Trump has vowed to block efforts to remove Confederate names from military bases.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I think this social anxiety we have to navigate all the time really did contribute to lower performance.” said Daniele Anderson, a former Navy officer.

item.title: Republicans Secure More Subpoena Power in Push to Discredit Russia Inquiry
item.description: Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee authorized their chairman to subpoena dozens of F.B.I. and former Obama administration officials, including a top aide to Joseph R. Biden Jr.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:description: “We need to look long and hard at how the Mueller investigation got off the rails,” said Senator Lindsey Graham, the Judiciary Committee chairman.

item.title: Where’s Airborne Plastic? Everywhere, Scientists Find.
item.description: There’s “no nook or cranny” on the planet where it doesn’t end up, the lead researcher on a new study said.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Beth Coller for The New York Times
item.media:description: A camp site in Arches National Park in Utah. Scientists were surprised to find tiny bits of plastic in remote areas.

item.title: G.O.P. Platform, Rolled Over From 2016, Condemns the ‘Current President’
item.description: After the Republican National Committee kept outdated language from four years ago, when Barack Obama was still president, the party’s platform includes more than three dozen unflattering references to those in power at the White House.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Annie Karni
item.media:description: The Republican Party has found itself in an awkward bind because of President Trump’s decision to move the location of his convention speech.

item.title: An N.Y. Street Is Named for Robert E. Lee. Officials Want That Changed.
item.description: Mayor Bill de Blasio joined two congressional lawmakers in urging the military to rename General Lee Avenue, a main street on an Army base in Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Lady Antebellum, Hit Country Trio, Changes Its Name in Wake of Protests
item.description: The band, now known as Lady A, wrote in a letter to fans that its eyes had been “opened wide” to the injustices black people face.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli
item.media:description: The country band Lady Antebellum will now be known by its nickname, Lady A.

item.title: Signal Is the Messaging App of the Protests
item.description: Organizers and demonstrators say they feel safer communicating with end-to-end encryption.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Toby Anderson, 30, at a Black Lives Matter protest in Providence, R.I., on June 5. Mr. Anderson said he downloaded Signal at his mother’s request. “She’s a black woman in America,” he told the Associated Press, explaining her concern for his safety.

item.title: Video Shows Black Man Pleading ‘I Can’t Breathe’ During 2019 Arrest in Oklahoma
item.description: An officer replied, “I don’t care,” and the man, Derrick Scott, died shortly afterward. This week, the Oklahoma City police released recordings of the May 2019 arrest.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri and Alan Yuhas

item.title: U.S. to Sanction I.C.C. Investigators in War Crimes Inquiry
item.description: The International Criminal Court has collected evidence of what it says is torture, rape and other crimes by American forces during the war in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Trump administration has long been at odds with the International Criminal Court.

item.title: As Playgrounds Start to Reopen, Here’s How to Keep Kids Safe
item.description: Parents and caregivers are weighing the risks of bringing children to playgrounds, where social distancing can be a challenge and hard surfaces are everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:description: There are no universal safety measures for parks across the country, like this one in Allentown, Pa. But experts agree social distancing, along with sanitizing hands regularly, can help.

item.title: Federal Arrests Show No Sign that Antifa Plotted Protests
item.description: Despite claims by President Trump and Attorney General William P. Barr, there is scant evidence that loosely organized anti-fascists are a significant player in protests.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Los Angeles Police Department said it saw no organized effort by antifa during protests in the city.

item.title: General Milley Apologizes for Trump Photo Op Role
item.description: President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square, current and former military leaders say, has started a moment of reckoning in the military.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: “As a commissioned uniformed officer, it was a mistake that I have learned from,” General Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said.

item.title: Live Protests Today Updates: George Floyd, Police and BLM
item.description: The country’s top military official apologized for taking part in President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square for a photo op after authorities cleared the area of peaceful protesters.
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: “As a commissioned uniformed officer, it was a mistake that I have learned from,” General Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said.

item.title: What Will the University of California Be Like in Fall?
item.description: Thursday: The University of California’s president talks about her tenure and the pandemic. Also: A shooting rattles Paso Robles; and reopening updates.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler and Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Janet Napolitano, the University of California president, during a meeting of the Commonwealth Club in 2018, in San Francisco.

item.title: Philonise Floyd Speaks Out: ‘I’m Here to Ask You to Make It Stop’
item.description: Congressional testimony and a new debate over Confederate names: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Covid-19 Patient Gets Double Lung Transplant, Offering Hope for Others
item.description: The operation is believed to be the first of its kind in the U.S. The patient, a woman in her 20s, had been healthy, but the coronavirus devastated her lungs.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:description: An extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, or ECMO, room, where coronavirus patients struggling to breathe are treated, at a Northwestern Medicine facility in Chicago.

item.title: Where Reopening Is Working
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: First day of phase one of reopening in Manhattan earlier this week.

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Stocks Dropping Sharply
item.description: Arizona, one of the U.S. states that began reopening earliest, is emerging as a hot spot. Known cases in Africa doubled in the last 18 days.
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction workers in Manhattan returned to work during the first phase of reopening on Monday.

item.title: One Bar. Twelve Weeks. Seventeen Lives in Lockdown.
item.description: Following an Oakland tavern and its staff — from the tattooed bartender to the undocumented cleaner — as they weather the economic and emotional fallout of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Louwenda Kachingwe, the owner of the Hatch, is known as Pancho. “The logical thing would just be to shut it down,” he said at one point. “But in this case, it’s about the people.”

item.title: Worried About Social Distancing When Traveling? Join the Crowd and Rent an R.V.
item.description: Recreational vehicles were gaining in popularity before the pandemic. Now, with travel restrictions loosening, a surge of travelers is drawn to the relative solitude that R.V.s offer.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: After Tragedy, Making a Place to Gather for Support and Solidarity
item.description: The memorial to George Floyd near Cup Foods in Minneapolis has become a place for the community to reflect.
item.dc:creator: Peter van Agtmael

item.title: When Do Unemployment Benefits Lapse? Congress Is at Odds Over an Extension
item.description: While some lawmakers want to continue substantial aid for millions of unemployed workers, others are concerned that the money is holding back a recovery that depends on employees returning to work.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, left, with Senator Rob Portman of Ohio during a committee hearing this week.

item.title: Libraries Strive to Stay ‘Community Living Rooms’ as They Reopen
item.description: Safely lending books is just the beginning. Libraries are figuring out everything from how to remain welcoming spaces to how to respond to changing reader behavior.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ridgeway Burns, working for the Hinsdale Public Library in Illinois, is delivering books by bike during the pandemic.

item.title: Biden’s Brain Trust on the Economy: Liberal and Sworn to Silence
item.description: The presumptive Democratic nominee relies on veteran advisers with Washington roots and has begun sounding out other economists on the ideological left, but his campaign will not say who really has his ear.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. sees the economic recovery as his foremost duty if he wins the presidency.

item.title: Live Stock Market Tracker and Economy Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The view of the New York Stock Exchange as seen from the steps of Federal Hall.

item.title: Solicitor General Noel Francisco Expected to Step Down
item.description: Mr. Francisco has represented the Trump administration before the Supreme Court, including in controversial cases like the travel ban against predominantly Muslim countries.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Noel J. Francisco, the solicitor general, has been a forceful advocate for President Trump.

item.title: Joe Biden, Emissary of Grief
item.description: His entire political career has been marked by personal loss. His allies say that makes him uniquely capable of leading a nation grappling with death.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:description: Mr. Biden eulogized Representative John Dingell of Michigan in February 2019.

item.title: Protesters Topple Statue of Jefferson Davis on Richmond’s Monument Avenue
item.description: A symbol of the Confederacy falls as demonstrations sparked by the death of George Floyd continue across the country.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A statue of Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederate States of America during the Civil War, had stood in Richmond, Va., since 1907.

item.title: Inside Seattle’s ‘Autonomous Zone’: Trump Criticizes Mayor Durkan
item.description: President Trump challenged Seattle’s mayor to “take back your city” after police vacated a precinct and protesters laid claim to the neighborhood around it.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: A gathering on Wednesday in the Seattle neighborhood of Capitol Hill, where protesters have established an “autonomous zone.”

item.title: Walmart Says It Will No Longer Lock Up African-American Beauty Products
item.description: The policy had been the subject of a racial discrimination lawsuit that was dropped last year, but the practice had come under renewed scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Elisha Brown

item.title: Trump Rejects Renaming Military Bases Named After Confederate Generals
item.description: By dismissing an idea under consideration by the Pentagon, the president positioned himself firmly against the movement to remove racist symbols and combat racism touched off by George Floyd’s death.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump met with African-American advisers and supporters on Wednesday at the White House.

item.title: Kamala Harris Is Done Explaining Racism
item.description: The senator and vice-presidential prospect has a message for her white friends who are surprised about police brutality.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times

item.title: PG&E Appoints a New Board as It Eyes Its Bankruptcy Exit
item.description: The governor of California required the troubled utility to replace its directors as a condition for taking part in a new wildfire liability fund.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Salgu Wissmath for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Pacific Gas & Electric’s board visited Paradise, Calif., a year after the Camp Fire tore through the town.

item.title: Museums Collect Protest Signs to Preserve History in Real Time
item.description: Curators surveyed the area outside the White House on Wednesday for artifacts that will help record the emotional turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fence at Lafayette Park, near the White House, filled with signs of protest made by people outraged by the police killing of George Floyd.

item.title: Trump Demands CNN Retract a Poll, as OANN Teases a Rosier View
item.description: The president’s campaign urged CNN to apologize for a poll that showed him well behind Joe Biden. Soon after, One America News suggested a more favorable survey was on the way.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: President Trump’s campaign called a poll by CNN, which showed him trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr., “phony” and “a stunt.” A CNN lawyer called the campaign’s letter “factually and legally baseless.”

item.title: Drawing on Decades of Activism, Karen Bass Leads Democrats’ Policing Overhaul
item.description: The California congresswoman, who heads the Congressional Black Caucus and was the first black woman speaker of a state legislature, has navigated internal divides to produce Democrats’ expansive bill.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:description: Representative Karen Bass has been an activist since long before she was even able to vote.

item.title: LeBron James and Other Stars Form a Voting Rights Group
item.description: “This is the time for us to finally make a difference,” the N.B.A. superstar said of the new group, which will aim to protect African-Americans’ voting rights.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:description: A new voting rights organization represents LeBron James’s most significant foray yet into electoral politics.

item.title: An Eyesore in Washington Becomes an Icon
item.description: Once reviled, the chain-link fence surrounding Lafayette Square and the White House is now seen as a bulletin board of art and artifacts dedicated to George Floyd and hope.
item.dc:creator: Mark Leibovich
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zayden and Angelica Cuevas looked at the protest signs attached to a fence surrounding the White House on Monday.

item.title: Marny Xiong, Progressive Dynamo in Minnesota, Dies at 31
item.description: A child of Hmong refugees, she was chair of the St. Paul school board. The coronavirus struck her and her father on the same day. He survived; she didn't.
item.dc:creator: John Leland

item.title: Pompeo Aide Who Pushed Saudi Arms Sale Said to Have Pressured Inspector General
item.description: Congress is looking into whether Secretary of State Mike Pompeo asked President Trump to fire Steve Linick, the department’s inspector general, to retaliate for investigations.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Michael LaForgia and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, in February.

item.title: Georgia’s Election Mess: Many Problems, Plenty of Blame, Few Solutions for November
item.description: Tuesday’s disastrous primary election was plagued by glitches, but Democrats also saw a systemic effort to disenfranchise voters.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: John Spink/Atlanta Journal-Constitution, via Associated Press
item.media:description: People waited in line to vote at Park Tavern in Atlanta on Tuesday.
